posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Hello

We observe behavioral differences between the PidController from the old (wpilibj) framework and the PidController from the new (math.controller) framework.

Namely, introducing a derivative gain in the new PidController seems to have a much more dramatic impact than it did with the old PidController.

Is this expected?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Are you running calculate with a different loop period than previously?  The D and I terms depend on the period.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thanks for your prompt reply!

We used to run the old PiDcontroller in a dedicated thread at 100 Hz and run the new one at the default 50 Hz in the main loop. The effect is much more draconian than what we would expect for just halving the frequency. The D parameter needs to be divided by multiple thousands between the old and new PIDController to observe a similar behavior.

posts.name: Eli Barnett

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked: Possibly. Is anybody else using the new PIDController? Are we supposed to set a non-default timing-related setting on it so that it behaves properly?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Define “properly.”  The old controller (it has been deprecated for several years now, I think?) may not have been normalized to seconds.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: The old PID controller’s I and D term calculations didn’t include period at all. We couldn’t fix that in the old implementation to make gain values period-agnostic because that would have broken everyone’s PID constants. The new PID controller multiplies by the period for I and divides by the period for D.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the great explanations! No fixes needed, but I am glad I now understand why copying PID values from old code using the old controller to new code using the new controller was not working.

May I suggest that you add some kind of warning note on the page hereunder to make it clear that switching from the old to the new PidController entails retuning I and D parameters (or suggest as a workaround to artificially force the period to 1)?

2020 Command-Based Rewrite: What Changed? — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation (wpilib.org)
